column4: Good Evening Ubuntu! Before 2010 finally dies, i have a question: Whats a good way to find all files that contain the word "cheese" but not the word "coke"?
find / -name "*cheese*"
just ignore iLinux, he's just a noob
if you want to get nitty-gritty, find / -name "*cheese*" | grep -v coke
that will not produce a list of files that contain cheese but no coke
yes, it will.
first of all, it will look for files with "cheese" in the name. not files with cheese in the file.
the way you asked the question, it sounded like you were looking for cheese and not coke only in the filenames, not within the files themselves, therefore the solution is sound
within the file.
read my question. "Whats a good way to find all files that contain the word". Im very precisely when it comes to words. Im a nerd, you know.
aah, in that case:  find / -type f -exec grep cheese {} \; | grep -v coke
that will search for lines that contain cheese but not coke. im searching for files.
feel free to troll elsewhere.
your line will spit out lines that contain cheese but not coke.
man grep  while you're at it
you dont get it. believe me, you are more noob then me.
here is a solution using awk: find . -type f -exec awk '/cheese/{f=1}/coke/{c=1;exit}END{exit !f ||c }' {} \; -print
but i would prefer grep. if there is an easy solution.
it's like I said, man grep
i dont think there is an easy solution with grep.
there never is when you're unwilling to do any real work and rely on others to do things for you.
usually it isn't so bad, but when you go out of your way like that...
